Pivotting

Source: vignettes/pivot.Rmd
pivot.Rmd

Introduction

This vignette describes the use of the new pivot() function.

There are two primary ways that pivot() differs from previous functions in tidyr, reshape2, and reshape:

  • The reshaping operation is specified with a data frame that describes precisely how metadata stored in column names becomes real data variables. This is inspired by the cdata package by John Mount and Nina Zumel.

  • Reshaping works with multiple measure variables that may have different types. This is inspired by the enhanced melt() and dcast() functions provided by the data.table package by Matt Dowle and Arun Srinivasan.

library(tidyr)
library(dplyr)
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter, lag
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union
library(readr)

Wide to long

Pew data

pew <- read_csv("pew.csv", col_types = list())
pew
#> # A tibble: 18 x 11
#>    religion `<$10k` `$10-20k` `$20-30k` `$30-40k` `$40-50k` `$50-75k`
#>    <chr>      <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>
#>  1 Agnostic      27        34        60        81        76       137
#>  2 Atheist       12        27        37        52        35        70
#>  3 Buddhist      27        21        30        34        33        58
#>  4 Catholic     418       617       732       670       638      1116
#>  5 Don’t k…      15        14        15        11        10        35
#>  6 Evangel…     575       869      1064       982       881      1486
#>  7 Hindu          1         9         7         9        11        34
#>  8 Histori…     228       244       236       238       197       223
#>  9 Jehovah…      20        27        24        24        21        30
#> 10 Jewish        19        19        25        25        30        95
#> 11 Mainlin…     289       495       619       655       651      1107
#> 12 Mormon        29        40        48        51        56       112
#> 13 Muslim         6         7         9        10         9        23
#> 14 Orthodox      13        17        23        32        32        47
#> 15 Other C…       9         7        11        13        13        14
#> 16 Other F…      20        33        40        46        49        63
#> 17 Other W…       5         2         3         4         2         7
#> 18 Unaffil…     217       299       374       365       341       528
#> # … with 4 more variables: `$75-100k` <dbl>, `$100-150k` <dbl>,
#> #   `>150k` <dbl>, `Don't know/refused` <dbl>

To tidy this data we first create a spec. We are tidying from wide to long so we use pivot_spec_long():

spec <- pew %>% pivot_spec_long(-1, "count", "income")
spec
#> # A tibble: 10 x 3
#>    col_name           measure income            
#>    <chr>              <chr>   <chr>             
#>  1 <$10k              count   <$10k             
#>  2 $10-20k            count   $10-20k           
#>  3 $20-30k            count   $20-30k           
#>  4 $30-40k            count   $30-40k           
#>  5 $40-50k            count   $40-50k           
#>  6 $50-75k            count   $50-75k           
#>  7 $75-100k           count   $75-100k          
#>  8 $100-150k          count   $100-150k         
#>  9 >150k              count   >150k             
#> 10 Don't know/refused count   Don't know/refused

  • The first argument describes which columns this transformation applies to. In this case, it’s every column apart from the first.

  • The cell_val gives the name of the variable stored in the cells. In this the case the values are measurements of counts.

  • The col_name gives the name of the variable stored in the column names. In this case, it’s an income range.

We can now achieve the desired reshaping by pivot pew with this spec:

pew %>% pivot(spec)
#> # A tibble: 180 x 3
#>    religion income             count
#>    <chr>    <chr>              <dbl>
#>  1 Agnostic <$10k                 27
#>  2 Agnostic $10-20k               12
#>  3 Agnostic $20-30k               27
#>  4 Agnostic $30-40k              418
#>  5 Agnostic $40-50k               15
#>  6 Agnostic $50-75k              575
#>  7 Agnostic $75-100k               1
#>  8 Agnostic $100-150k            228
#>  9 Agnostic >150k                 20
#> 10 Agnostic Don't know/refused    19
#> # … with 170 more rows

Billboard

Similar to pew, but the variable encoded in the columns is not a string, and requires some additional manipulation to extract:

billboard <- read_csv("billboard.csv", col_types = list()) %>%
  mutate_at(vars(starts_with("wk")), as.numeric)
billboard
#> # A tibble: 317 x 81
#>     year artist track time  date.entered   wk1   wk2   wk3   wk4   wk5
#>    <dbl> <chr>  <chr> <tim> <date>       <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#>  1  2000 2 Pac  Baby… 04:22 2000-02-26      87    82    72    77    87
#>  2  2000 2Ge+h… The … 03:15 2000-09-02      91    87    92    NA    NA
#>  3  2000 3 Doo… Kryp… 03:53 2000-04-08      81    70    68    67    66

#> #   wk19 <dbl>, wk20 <dbl>, wk21 <dbl>, wk22 <dbl>, wk23 <dbl>,
#> #   wk24 <dbl>, wk25 <dbl>, wk26 <dbl>, wk27 <dbl>, wk28 <dbl>,
#> #   wk29 <dbl>, wk30 <dbl>, wk31 <dbl>, wk32 <dbl>, wk33 <dbl>,
#> #   wk34 <dbl>, wk35 <dbl>, wk36 <dbl>, wk37 <dbl>, wk38 <dbl>,
#> #   wk39 <dbl>, wk40 <dbl>, wk41 <dbl>, wk42 <dbl>, wk43 <dbl>,
#> #   wk44 <dbl>, wk45 <dbl>, wk46 <dbl>, wk47 <dbl>, wk48 <dbl>,
#> #   wk49 <dbl>, wk50 <dbl>, wk51 <dbl>, wk52 <dbl>, wk53 <dbl>,
#> #   wk54 <dbl>, wk55 <dbl>, wk56 <dbl>, wk57 <dbl>, wk58 <dbl>,
#> #   wk59 <dbl>, wk60 <dbl>, wk61 <dbl>, wk62 <dbl>, wk63 <dbl>,
#> #   wk64 <dbl>, wk65 <dbl>, wk66 <dbl>, wk67 <dbl>, wk68 <dbl>,
#> #   wk69 <dbl>, wk70 <dbl>, wk71 <dbl>, wk72 <dbl>, wk73 <dbl>,
#> #   wk74 <dbl>, wk75 <dbl>, wk76 <dbl>
billboard %>% pivot_spec_long(starts_with("wk"), "rank", "week")
#> # A tibble: 76 x 3
#>    col_name measure week 
#>    <chr>    <chr>   <chr>
#>  1 wk1      rank    wk1  
#>  2 wk2      rank    wk2  
#>  3 wk3      rank    wk3  
#>  4 wk4      rank    wk4  
#>  5 wk5      rank    wk5  
#>  6 wk6      rank    wk6  
#>  7 wk7      rank    wk7  
#>  8 wk8      rank    wk8  
#>  9 wk9      rank    wk9  
#> 10 wk10     rank    wk10 
#> # … with 66 more rows
spec <- billboard %>%
  pivot_spec_long(starts_with("wk"), "rank", "week") %>%
  mutate(week = parse_number(week))
spec
#> # A tibble: 76 x 3
#>    col_name measure  week
#>    <chr>    <chr>   <dbl>
#>  1 wk1      rank        1
#>  2 wk2      rank        2
#>  3 wk3      rank        3
#>  4 wk4      rank        4
#>  5 wk5      rank        5
#>  6 wk6      rank        6
#>  7 wk7      rank        7
#>  8 wk8      rank        8
#>  9 wk9      rank        9
#> 10 wk10     rank       10
#> # … with 66 more rows
billboard %>% pivot(spec)
#> # A tibble: 24,092 x 7
#>     year artist track                   time   date.entered  week  rank
#>    <dbl> <chr>  <chr>                   <time> <date>       <dbl> <dbl>
#>  1  2000 2 Pac  Baby Don't Cry (Keep... 04:22  2000-02-26       1    87

WHO tuberculosis data

In more complex cases, the column name might encode multiple variables, and require significant parsing to extract.

who
#> # A tibble: 7,240 x 60
#>    country iso2  iso3   year new_sp_m014 new_sp_m1524 new_sp_m2534
#>    <chr>   <chr> <chr> <int>       <int>        <int>        <int>
#>  1 Afghan… AF    AFG    1980          NA           NA           NA
#>  2 Afghan… AF    AFG    1981          NA           NA           NA
#>  3 Afghan… AF    AFG    1982          NA           NA           NA
#>  4 Afghan… AF    AFG    1983          NA           NA           NA
#>  5 Afghan… AF    AFG    1984          NA           NA           NA
#>  6 Afghan… AF    AFG    1985          NA           NA           NA
#>  7 Afghan… AF    AFG    1986          NA           NA           NA
#>  8 Afghan… AF    AFG    1987          NA           NA           NA
#>  9 Afghan… AF    AFG    1988          NA           NA           NA
#> 10 Afghan… AF    AFG    1989          NA           NA           NA
#> # … with 7,230 more rows, and 53 more variables: new_sp_m3544 <int>,
#> #   new_sp_m4554 <int>, new_sp_m5564 <int>, new_sp_m65 <int>,
#> #   new_sp_f014 <int>, new_sp_f1524 <int>, new_sp_f2534 <int>,
#> #   new_sp_f3544 <int>, new_sp_f4554 <int>, new_sp_f5564 <int>,
#> #   new_sp_f65 <int>, new_sn_m014 <int>, new_sn_m1524 <int>,
#> #   new_sn_m2534 <int>, new_sn_m3544 <int>, new_sn_m4554 <int>,
#> #   new_sn_m5564 <int>, new_sn_m65 <int>, new_sn_f014 <int>,
#> #   new_sn_f1524 <int>, new_sn_f2534 <int>, new_sn_f3544 <int>,
#> #   new_sn_f4554 <int>, new_sn_f5564 <int>, new_sn_f65 <int>,
#> #   new_ep_m014 <int>, new_ep_m1524 <int>, new_ep_m2534 <int>,
#> #   new_ep_m3544 <int>, new_ep_m4554 <int>, new_ep_m5564 <int>,
#> #   new_ep_m65 <int>, new_ep_f014 <int>, new_ep_f1524 <int>,
#> #   new_ep_f2534 <int>, new_ep_f3544 <int>, new_ep_f4554 <int>,
#> #   new_ep_f5564 <int>, new_ep_f65 <int>, newrel_m014 <int>,
#> #   newrel_m1524 <int>, newrel_m2534 <int>, newrel_m3544 <int>,
#> #   newrel_m4554 <int>, newrel_m5564 <int>, newrel_m65 <int>,
#> #   newrel_f014 <int>, newrel_f1524 <int>, newrel_f2534 <int>,
#> #   newrel_f3544 <int>, newrel_f4554 <int>, newrel_f5564 <int>,
#> #   newrel_f65 <int>
who %>% pivot_spec_long(new_sp_m014:newrel_f65)
#> # A tibble: 56 x 3
#>    col_name     measure variable    
#>    <chr>        <chr>   <chr>       
#>  1 new_sp_m014  value   new_sp_m014 
#>  2 new_sp_m1524 value   new_sp_m1524
#>  3 new_sp_m2534 value   new_sp_m2534
#>  4 new_sp_m3544 value   new_sp_m3544
#>  5 new_sp_m4554 value   new_sp_m4554
#>  6 new_sp_m5564 value   new_sp_m5564
#>  7 new_sp_m65   value   new_sp_m65  
#>  8 new_sp_f014  value   new_sp_f014 
#>  9 new_sp_f1524 value   new_sp_f1524
#> 10 new_sp_f2534 value   new_sp_f2534
#> # … with 46 more rows

spec <- who %>%
  pivot_spec_long(new_sp_m014:newrel_f65, "count") %>%
  extract(variable, c("diagnosis", "gender", "age"), "new_?(.*)_(.)(.*)") %>%
  mutate(age = factor(age, levels = unique(age), ordered = TRUE))
spec
#> # A tibble: 56 x 5
#>    col_name     measure diagnosis gender age  
#>    <chr>        <chr>   <chr>     <chr>  <ord>
#>  1 new_sp_m014  count   sp        m      014  
#>  2 new_sp_m1524 count   sp        m      1524 
#>  3 new_sp_m2534 count   sp        m      2534 
#>  4 new_sp_m3544 count   sp        m      3544 
#>  5 new_sp_m4554 count   sp        m      4554 
#>  6 new_sp_m5564 count   sp        m      5564 
#>  7 new_sp_m65   count   sp        m      65   
#>  8 new_sp_f014  count   sp        f      014  
#>  9 new_sp_f1524 count   sp        f      1524 
#> 10 new_sp_f2534 count   sp        f      2534 
#> # … with 46 more rows
who %>% pivot(spec, na.rm = TRUE)
#> # A tibble: 76,046 x 8
#>    country     iso2  iso3   year diagnosis gender age   count
#>    <chr>       <chr> <chr> <int> <chr>     <chr>  <ord> <int>
#>  1 Afghanistan AF    AFG    1980 sn        m      3544      0
#>  2 Afghanistan AF    AFG    1980 sn        m      4554     30
#>  3 Afghanistan AF    AFG    1980 sn        m      5564      8
#>  4 Afghanistan AF    AFG    1980 sn        m      65       52
#>  5 Afghanistan AF    AFG    1980 sn        f      014     129
#>  6 Afghanistan AF    AFG    1980 sn        f      1524     90
#>  7 Afghanistan AF    AFG    1980 sn        f      2534    127
#>  8 Afghanistan AF    AFG    1980 sn        f      3544    139
#>  9 Afghanistan AF    AFG    1980 sn        f      4554    151
#> 10 Afghanistan AF    AFG    1980 sn        f      5564    193
#> # … with 76,036 more rows

Multiple value columns

From https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/data.table/vignettes/datatable-reshape.html

family <- tibble::tribble(
  ~family_id, ~age_mother,  ~dob_child1,  ~dob_child2, ~gender_child1, ~gender_child2,
          1L,         30L, "1998-11-26", "2000-01-29",             1L,             2L,
          2L,         27L, "1996-06-22",           NA,             2L,             NA,
          3L,         26L, "2002-07-11", "2004-04-05",             2L,             2L,
          4L,         32L, "2004-10-10", "2009-08-27",             1L,             1L,
          5L,         29L, "2000-12-05", "2005-02-28",             2L,             1L,
) %>%
  mutate_at(vars(starts_with("dob")), parse_date)

spec <- family %>%
  pivot_spec_long(-(1:2)) %>%
  separate(variable, c("measure", "child")) %>%
  mutate(child = parse_number(child))

family %>%
  select(-age_mother) %>%
  pivot(spec, na.rm = TRUE)
#> # A tibble: 9 x 4
#>   family_id child dob        gender
#>       <int> <dbl> <date>      <int>
#> 1         1     1 1998-11-26      1
#> 2         1     2 1996-06-22      2
#> 3         2     1 2002-07-11      2
#> 4         2     2 2004-10-10      1
#> 5         3     1 2000-12-05      2
#> 6         3     2 2000-01-29      2
#> 7         4     2 2004-04-05      2
#> 8         5     1 2009-08-27      1
#> 9         5     2 2005-02-28      1

Census data

Lightly modified from Table 5 “completions” found at https://www.census.gov/construction/nrc/index.html.

construction <- read_csv("construction.csv", col_types = list("2 to 4 units" = col_integer()))
construction
#> # A tibble: 10 x 10
#>     Year Month Total `1 unit` `2 to 4 units` `5 units or mor… Northeast
#>    <dbl> <chr> <dbl>    <dbl>          <int>            <dbl>     <dbl>
#>  1  2017 Dece…  1197      837             NA              347       115
#>  2  2018 Janu…  1218      859             NA              348       114
#>  3  2018 Febr…  1289      882             NA              400       138
#>  4  2018 March  1229      862             NA              356       150
#>  5  2018 April  1257      797             NA              447       144
#>  6  2018 May    1251      875             NA              364        90
#>  7  2018 June   1216      867             NA              342        76
#>  8  2018 July   1195      829             NA              360       108
#>  9  2018 Augu…  1230      939             NA              286        90
#> 10  2018 Sept…  1148      835             NA              304       117
#> # … with 3 more variables: Midwest <dbl>, South <dbl>, West <dbl>
# multiple variables encoded, but no way to parse; must manually specify

spec <- tribble(
  ~col_name,         ~units,  ~region,      ~measure,
  "Total",            "total", NA,          "n",
  "1 unit",           "1",     NA,          "n",
  "2 to 4 units",     "2-4",   NA,          "n",
  "5 units or more",  "5+",    NA,          "n",
  "Northeast",        NA,      "Northeast", "n",
  "Midwest",          NA,      "Midwest",   "n",
  "South",            NA,      "South",     "n",
  "West",             NA,      "West",      "n",
)
spec
#> # A tibble: 8 x 4
#>   col_name        units region    measure
#>   <chr>           <chr> <chr>     <chr>  
#> 1 Total           total <NA>      n      
#> 2 1 unit          1     <NA>      n      
#> 3 2 to 4 units    2-4   <NA>      n      
#> 4 5 units or more 5+    <NA>      n      
#> 5 Northeast       <NA>  Northeast n      
#> 6 Midwest         <NA>  Midwest   n      
#> 7 South           <NA>  South     n      
#> 8 West            <NA>  West      n

construction %>% pivot(spec)
#> # A tibble: 80 x 5
#>     Year Month    units region        n
#>    <dbl> <chr>    <chr> <chr>     <dbl>
#>  1  2017 December total <NA>       1197
#>  2  2017 December 1     <NA>       1218
#>  3  2017 December 2-4   <NA>       1289
#>  4  2017 December 5+    <NA>       1229
#>  5  2017 December <NA>  Northeast  1257
#>  6  2017 December <NA>  Midwest    1251
#>  7  2017 December <NA>  South      1216
#>  8  2017 December <NA>  West       1195
#>  9  2018 January  total <NA>       1230
#> 10  2018 January  1     <NA>       1148
#> # … with 70 more rows

Long to wide

Single measure

From http://stackoverflow.com/questions/24929954

df <- expand_grid(
    Product = c("A", "B"), 
    Country = c("AI", "EI"), 
    Year = 2000:2014
  ) %>%
  mutate(value = rnorm(nrow(.))) %>%
  filter((Product == "A" & Country == "AI") | (Product == "B" & Country == "EI"))

spec <- df %>% 
  expand(Product, Country, measure = "value") %>% 
  mutate(
    col_name = paste0(Product, "_", Country)
  )
spec
#> # A tibble: 4 x 4
#>   Product Country measure col_name
#>   <chr>   <chr>   <chr>   <chr>   
#> 1 A       AI      value   A_AI    
#> 2 A       EI      value   A_EI    
#> 3 B       AI      value   B_AI    
#> 4 B       EI      value   B_EI

df %>% pivot(spec) %>% head()
#> # A tibble: 6 x 5
#>    Year    A_AI  A_EI  B_AI   B_EI
#>   <int>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl>
#> 1  2000  0.399     NA    NA -0.543
#> 2  2001  0.0768    NA    NA -0.283
#> 3  2002 -0.0663    NA    NA  1.19 
#> 4  2003 -0.747     NA    NA  0.670
#> 5  2004  0.562     NA    NA -0.379
#> 6  2005 -0.979     NA    NA  0.879

Multiple measure

(From Jenny Bryan)

input <- tribble(
  ~hw,   ~name,  ~mark,   ~pr,
  "hw1", "anna",    95,  "ok",
  "hw1", "alan",    90, "meh",
  "hw1", "carl",    85,  "ok",
  "hw2", "alan",    70, "meh",
  "hw2", "carl",    80,  "ok"
)

spec <- input %>% 
  expand(hw, measure = c("mark", "pr")) %>% 
  mutate(
    col_name = paste0(hw, "_", measure)
  )
spec
#> # A tibble: 4 x 3
#>   hw    measure col_name
#>   <chr> <chr>   <chr>   
#> 1 hw1   mark    hw1_mark
#> 2 hw1   pr      hw1_pr  
#> 3 hw2   mark    hw2_mark
#> 4 hw2   pr      hw2_pr

input %>% pivot(spec)
#> # A tibble: 3 x 5
#>   name  hw1_mark hw2_mark hw1_pr hw2_pr
#>   <chr>    <dbl>    <dbl> <chr>  <chr> 
#> 1 anna        95       NA ok     <NA>  
#> 2 alan        90       70 meh    meh   
#> 3 carl        85       80 ok     ok

Multiple transformations

Weather data

# need to pivot in both directions

weather <- read_csv("weather.csv", col_types = list()) 

weather %>% pivot_spec_long(d1:d31, "temp", "day")
#> # A tibble: 31 x 3
#>    col_name measure day  
#>    <chr>    <chr>   <chr>
#>  1 d1       temp    d1   
#>  2 d2       temp    d2   
#>  3 d3       temp    d3   
#>  4 d4       temp    d4   
#>  5 d5       temp    d5   
#>  6 d6       temp    d6   
#>  7 d7       temp    d7   
#>  8 d8       temp    d8   
#>  9 d9       temp    d9   
#> 10 d10      temp    d10  
#> # … with 21 more rows

weather_spec <- weather %>%
  pivot_spec_long(d1:d31, "temp", "day") %>%
  mutate(day = parse_number(day))
weather_spec
#> # A tibble: 31 x 3
#>    col_name measure   day
#>    <chr>    <chr>   <dbl>
#>  1 d1       temp        1
#>  2 d2       temp        2
#>  3 d3       temp        3
#>  4 d4       temp        4
#>  5 d5       temp        5
#>  6 d6       temp        6
#>  7 d7       temp        7
#>  8 d8       temp        8
#>  9 d9       temp        9
#> 10 d10      temp       10
#> # … with 21 more rows
weather2 <- pivot(weather, weather_spec, na.rm = TRUE)
weather2
#> # A tibble: 66 x 6
#>    id       year month element   day  temp
#>    <chr>   <dbl> <dbl> <chr>   <dbl> <dbl>
#>  1 MX17004  2010     1 tmax       21  29.9
#>  2 MX17004  2010     1 tmax       22  13.8
#>  3 MX17004  2010     1 tmax       25  27.3
#>  4 MX17004  2010     1 tmax       26  14.4
#>  5 MX17004  2010     1 tmin       10  31.3
#>  6 MX17004  2010     1 tmin       11  16.3
#>  7 MX17004  2010     1 tmin       16  24.1
#>  8 MX17004  2010     1 tmin       17  14.4
#>  9 MX17004  2010     1 tmin       26  28.6
#> 10 MX17004  2010     1 tmin       27  17.5
#> # … with 56 more rows

spec2 <- weather2 %>% pivot_spec_wide(element, temp)
spec2
#> # A tibble: 2 x 3
#>   col_name measure element
#>   <chr>    <chr>   <chr>  
#> 1 tmax     temp    tmax   
#> 2 tmin     temp    tmin
weather2 %>% pivot(spec2)
#> # A tibble: 63 x 6
#>    id       year month   day  tmax  tmin
#>    <chr>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>
#>  1 MX17004  2010     1    21  29.9  NA  
#>  2 MX17004  2010     1    22  13.8  NA  
#>  3 MX17004  2010     1    25  27.3  NA  
#>  4 MX17004  2010     1    26  14.4  28.6
#>  5 MX17004  2010     1    10  NA    31.3
#>  6 MX17004  2010     1    11  NA    16.3
#>  7 MX17004  2010     1    16  NA    24.1
#>  8 MX17004  2010     1    17  NA    14.4
#>  9 MX17004  2010     1    27  NA    17.5
#> 10 MX17004  2010     2    23  27.2  NA  
#> # … with 53 more rows

Contact list

Requires to widening twice.

Inspired by https://github.com/jienagu/tidyverse_examples/blob/master/example_long_wide.R

contacts <- 
  c(
    "company", "Toyota", "name", "Jiena McLellan",
    "company", "McDonalds", "name", "John Smith"
  )

df <- tibble(meta = contacts)
df <- df %>% 
  mutate(
    id = cumsum(meta == "company"),
    row = rep(seq_len(nrow(df) / 2), each = 2),
    type = rep(c("var", "value"), length = nrow(df))
  ) 

spec <- pivot_spec_wide(df, type, meta)
df2 <- df %>% pivot(spec)

spec2 <- pivot_spec_wide(df2, var, value)
df2 %>% select(-row) %>% pivot(spec2)
#> # A tibble: 2 x 3
#>      id company   name          
#>   <int> <chr>     <chr>         
#> 1     1 Toyota    Jiena McLellan
#> 2     2 McDonalds John Smith
